questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about criminal negligence?

choices.text: Contributory negligence constitutes as a defense
A case between the state and the accused doctor
Accused doctor is liable to punishment with imprisonment or fine or both
Even the risk of injury is punishable, even if nobody is hurt

questions.solution:
Contributory negligence can be cited as a defense in civil negligence and not in criminal negligence cases.

Contributory negligence is used to describe the plaintiff's contribution towards the damage caused by the negligent act of the accused doctor (defendant). In such a case, the accused doctor must prove that the plaintiff neglected to take sufficient care of his own health and safety, which in turn contributed to their suffering.  

 Factor Civil negligence  Criminal negligence 
Negligence  Lack of competent care and skill in the professional behavior Gross carelessness and lack of regard for patient's welfare
Contributory Negligence It may be cited as a defense for the doctor Does not constitute a defense for the doctor
Litigation  Between two parties   Between state and doctor  (option B)
Criteria for punishment  No action if the act has not resulted in harm/damage Bare negligence with risk of injury is punishable, despite nobody being hurt (option D)
Trial by Civil court   Criminal court  
Evidence    Strong evidence is sufficient    Guilt must be proved beyond reasonable doubt  
Punishment   Liable to pay damages Imprisonment  or fine or both (option B)

questions.text: If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a Court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same question based on the same set of facts. This is known as:
questions.solution:
If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a Court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same question based on the same set of facts and this is known as Res Judicata.

Defences Against Negligence

  • No duty is owed to the plaintiff
  • Duty discharged according to prevailing standards
  • Error of judgment
  • Contributory negligence - the absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient or his personal attendant
  • Res judicata (Section 337, BNSS) -If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a Court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same question based on the same set of facts.

Other options:

Option A: 'Res Ipsa Loquitor' means 'the thing or fact speaks for itself'. It is obvious evidence of the negligent act committed. For example, swabs left in the abdominal cavity post laparotomy.

Option C & D: Limitation (Res indicata)- A suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed. But, where a breach of duty to provide care as per a particular contract between a patient and a doctor is committed, legal action can be initiated up to three years from the date of alleged negligence.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: First Class judicial magistrate may pass a maximum sentence of _______.

choices.text: Imprisonment upto 1 year and fine of Rs 10,000
Imprisonment upto 3 years and a fine of Rs 50,000
Imprisonment upto 7 years and unlimited fine
Death sentence but it must be confirmed by high court

questions.solution:
The maximum sentence that a Judicial Magistrate of the First Class may pass is imprisonment up to 3 years and a fine of Rs 50,000.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about summons is false?

BNS - BHARATIYA NYAYA SANHITA

choices.text: Conduct money is offered to the witness irrespective of type of case
It is a document compelling the attendance of  witness in the court
Criminal courts have priority over civil courts
208 BNS deals with punishment for non-attendance

questions.solution:
Conduct money is provided only in civil cases.

Conduct money is the fee paid to the witness at the time of serving summons. This is provided in civil cases to meet the expenses for attending the court. In criminal cases, no fee is paid to the witness at the time of serving the summons. However, in criminal cases, conveyance charges and daily allowance can be claimed by the doctor according to Government rules. 

Summons

A summons is a document compelling the attendance of a witness in a Court of law under penalty, on a particular day, time, and for the purpose of giving evidence. (Option B)

questions.text:
A police sub-inspector brings the accused in a rape case to a doctor and requests a medical examination. He believes that examination findings would yield evidence to prove the offense allegedly committed. However, the accused is not cooperative. Under which section of BNSS (CrPC) can the doctor examine the accused?

CrPC - Criminal Procedure Code

BNSS - BHARATIYA NAGARIK SURAKSHA SANHITA
questions.solution:
The doctor can examine the accused using force under section 52 BNSS (Section 53 CrPC) as requested by the sub-inspector.

Section 52 BNSS (Section 53-A CrPC) states that when a person is arrested for rape or attempted rape, and there is a reasonable belief that examining their body could provide evidence of the crime, a registered medical practitioner (RMP) employed by a government or local authority hospital is permitted to conduct the examination. If such a practitioner is not available within a 16-kilometre radius of the crime scene, any other RMP can perform the examination at the request of a police officer. The practitioner, along with anyone assisting them in good faith and under their direction, is allowed to use necessary and reasonable force to carry out the examination.

Other options:

Option A: Section 337 BNSS (300 CrPC) - Person once convicted or acquitted not to be tried for the same offence.

Option B: Section 184 BNSS (164A CrPC) deals with the examination of the victim of rape by a medical expert with the consent of the woman or of a person competent to give such consent.

Option D: Section 53 BNSS (54 CrPC): Examination of arrested person by a medical officer. When any person is arrested, he shall be examined by a medical officer in the service of the Central Government or a State Government.

questions.text: An unidentified woman was rescued from a building collapse with her leg developing signs of gangrene. The trauma surgeon decided to conduct an above-knee amputation without her consent, considering the risk of sepsis. According to which section of the BNS is this not considered an offense?
questions.solution:
The emergency amputation performed by the surgeon is an act done in good faith for the benefit of a patient when obtaining consent is not possible. This is not an offense according to section 30 of the BNS.

Section 30 of the BNS states that an act done in good faith for the benefit of a person without consent is not punishable when the circumstances don't allow obtaining consent in time for the act of benefit.

Other options:

Option A: Section 25 of the BNS: Acts done with consent that are not intended or expected to cause death or grievous hurt are not considered offense.

Option B: Section 27 of the BNS: An action performed in good faith for the benefit of a child under 12 years of age or a person with a mental illness, with the consent of a parent or guardian, is not considered an offense.

Option D: Section 28 of the BNS: Consent is considered invalid if given under misconception or fear, or when given by a person of unsound mind.

questions.text: Which of the following will not be seen in a well-executed judicial hanging?
questions.solution:
A well-executed judicial hanging will not exhibit asphyxial signs.

The legal death sentence in India is carried out by hanging the criminal. The face of the person is covered with a dark mask and he is made to stand on a platform over trapdoors, which open downwards when a blot is drawn.

The rope is looped around the neck with the knot under the angle of the right jaw and the person is allowed to drop for 5-7 meters according to weight, age, and build of the person.

Sudden stopage of the moving body causes fracture dislocation usually at the C2-C3 or C3-C4 vertebra level. Bilateral fractures of either the pedicles or laminae of the arch of the second, third or fourth cervical vertebrae occurs (hangman's fracture) 

With proper judicial hanging, the brain stem ruptures between the pons and the medulla, destroying the reticular formation and resulting in an irreversible loss of consciousness. Destruction of respiratory centres also results in irreversible apnea.

Death is instantaneous but heartbeat may continue for 15-20 minutes and spasmodic muscle jerking may occur for a considerable time. Asphyxial signs are not seen in properly performed judicial hangings.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 52-year-old man commits a crime and is under trial. His lawyer presents a medical certificate for the man, stating that he has had schizophrenia for the past 30 years. This person will not be held guilty under which Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) section?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a person with a history of schizophrenia will not be held guilty under BNS (Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita) Section 22. The law states that an act of a person of an unsound mind (schizophrenia in this case) is not liable for punishment or prosecution.

Other options:

Option A: BNS - Section 21 states that a child of 7–12 years without proper mental maturity is not liable for the act.

Option C: BNS - Section 23 states that a person who commits an offense under involuntary intoxication is not liable for the act.

Option D: BNS - Section 24 states that a person who commits an offense under voluntary intoxication is liable for the act.

questions.text:
Section 90 of the BNS deals with ____

BNS - Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita

choices.text: Causing miscarriage with the consent of the mother
Causing miscarriage without the consent of the mother
Death of the mother by an act done with intent to cause miscarriage
Causing the death of the quick unborn child by an act amounting to culpable homicide

questions.solution:
Section 90 of the BNS deals with the death of the mother caused by an act done with intent to cause miscarriage.

Section 90(1) of BNS, states that if the woman dies because of a miscarriage, which is done with her consent shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term that may extend to ten years and shall also be liable to a fine.

Section 90(2) of BNS, states that when a miscarriage leading to the death of the woman is done without the consent of the woman, it shall be punishable either with imprisonment for life or with the punishment specified in the sub-section (1).

Related sections:

  • Section 88 of BNS states that miscarriage induced not for the purpose of saving the life/good of the woman, be punished with imprisonment for 3 years. If the woman is “quick with child” the period is extended for 7 years more. (Option A)
  • Section 89 of BNS, states that if miscarriage is done without the consent of the woman, the punishment is life imprisonment (Option B)
  • Section 92 of BNS, states that an act leading to the death of a quick unborn child, done with the intention of preventing a child from being born alive, is guilty of culpable homicide and shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term that may extend to ten years and shall also be liable to a fine. (Option D)
  • Section 93 of BNS, exposure or abandoning children are both punishable.
  • Section 94 of BNS – concealment of birth and secret disposal of the fetus are punishable.

Note- The phrase “quick with child” refers to advanced pregnancy when quickening can be felt.

questions.text: The mental ability of a person to make a valid will is known as _______________.
questions.solution:
The mental ability of a person to make a will is called testamentary capacity (testament = will).

A valid will is a written, duly signed, and witnessed document. At the time of making the will, the testator must be major and of sound disposing mind such that he can dispose of his property with understanding and reason.

A person affected by delusions can make a will if the delusion is not related in any way to the disposal of property or the persons affected. During the period of lucid interval, a mentally ill person can make a valid will.

The testator appoints an executor to carry out the terms of his will after his death.

Other options:

Option A: Mens rea (guilty mind) in criminal law refers to the state of mind of a defendant who is accused of committing a crime. Actus reus refers to the actual physical act causing death.

Option B: Corpus delicti, also known as the body of offence, says that a crime must be proved to have occurred before a person can be convicted of committing that crime.

Option D: Compos mentis- Before documenting a dying declaration, the doctor has to ascertain that the person is conscious and of sound mind with normal mental faculties (compos mentis).

questions.text: In the recently passed law for replacing the colonial legal sections, which of the following is the replacement of the Indian Evidence Act (IEA)?
questions.solution:
In the recent change in legal sections, the Indian Evidence Act (IEA) has been replaced by Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam (BSA).

Other options:

Option A: Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita is the official criminal code in the Republic of India. It took effect on July 1, 2024, replacing the Indian Penal Code after being passed by the parliament in December 2023.

Option B: Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita is the main legislation in India for administering substantive criminal law and aims to consolidate and amend the law relating to Criminal Procedure.

Option D: Bhartiya Nagarik Sakshya Sanhita is a redundant option since such a law does not exist in our constitution.

questions.text: A person is not exempt from criminal responsibility when he commits a crime in which of the following states?
questions.solution:
The person is not exempt from criminal responsibility when he commits a crime during voluntary drunkenness.

  • Somnambulism (Option B) also known as sleepwalking, is when people get up and walk around while asleep.
  • Somolentia
  • Delirium tremens (Option C) - It is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal. It involves sudden and severe mental or nervous system changes.
  • Involuntary drunkenness
  • Post-traumatic automatism
  • Oneroid state (Option D) - A dream-like fantastic delusional derangement of consciousness, is characterized by a kaleidoscopic quality of psychopathological experiences, wherein reality, illusions and hallucinations are merged into one. It is typically accompanied by motor and, in particular, catatonic disturbances.
  • Twilight state

The tests to determine criminal responsibility include:

  • McNaughten's rule (included in Sec. 84 of IPC)
  • Durham rule
  • Curren’s rule
  • The Irresistible Impulse Test (New Hampshire Doctrine)

  • The Federal Rule

questions.text: A middle-aged patient with a duodenal diverticulum who underwent surgery the previous day and has been nil per os since the surgery complains of abdominal pain. The surgeon was wearing a bracelet with a coin attached during the surgery despite being warned by the nurse. The abdominal radiograph is shown below. Under which doctrine will the surgeon be held responsible?
questions.solution:
The image shows a coin in the abdomen that was absent before the surgery. As the patient was nil per os after the surgery, this implies that the coin from the bracelet had fallen inside the abdomen during the surgery and the surgeon completed the surgery without removing it. The surgeon will be held responsible under res ipsa loquitur.

Res ipsa loquitur means "the thing or fact speaks for itself." It implies that the negligent act is so obvious that the patient need not prove the negligence. The patient has to only state the negligent act. This doctrine applies to both civil and criminal negligence. All of the following conditions should be fulfilled for this doctrine:

  • In the absence of negligence, there would not have been any injury usually.
  • The doctor had complete control over the injury-producing instrument or treatment.
  • The patient was not a part of contributory negligence.

Other options:

Option A - Res indicata is a defense for the doctor against negligence. This specifies that a suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed beyond two years would be dismissed as it would be beyond the period of limitation.

Option C - Contributory negligence is the absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient or his personal attendant along with the doctor's negligence contributing to the injury without which the injury would not have occurred. It acts as a partial defense against negligence for the doctor. In the given scenario, the patient was nil per os, indicating that there was no provision for foreign body consumption and suggesting there is no contributory negligence by the patient.

Option D - Medical maloccurrence occurs when the patient does not respond properly or faces adverse effects in spite of good attention and care by the doctor.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: According to the Warning Notice published by the Medical Council of India, a registered medical practitioner has been found guilty under the provision of advertising. Which of the following instances may not amount to professional misconduct under this provision?

choices.text: Putting up a signboard at a pharmacy where he does not work
Notifying the media twice that he is resuming his practice
Giving interviews about illnesses in an attempt to promote oneself
Indirectly promoting oneself through manufacturing firms

questions.solution:
A registered medical practitioner who intends to resume his practice is only permitted to notify the media twice. If he repeats it more than two times, he will face charges of professional misconduct.

The Medical Council of India and other State Medical Councils have published a Code of Medical Ethics, which specifies certain rules of conduct that a registered medical practitioner must adhere to.

Any person found guilty of any of the acts of commission or omissions listed in the Medical Council of India's Warning Notice will be considered to have engaged in professional misconduct and will be subjected to disciplinary action.

The important offences may be described as "the 6 A's". (1) Adultery arising out of professional relationship (2) Advertising (3) Abortion (unlawful) (4) Association with unqualified persons in professional matters (5) Addiction (6) Alcohol.

Offences under advertising include: 

  • A physician should not contribute to the lay press articles and give interviews regarding illnesses and treatments in an attempt to promote oneself. (option C)
  • He should not advertise himself through manufacturing firms directly or indirectly. (option D)
  • He should not put up a signboard at a pharmacy where he doesn't work. (option A)
  • It is illegal for a physician to use an unusually large signboard and write anything other than his name, qualifications, his speciality and registration number, including the name of the State Medical Council under which he is registered. His prescription papers should also have the same information.
  • A physician may notify the public or professional press of the beginning of his practice, the stoppage or resuming of it after a long period, or a change of address, but such a notification may appear no more than twice.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old recently married woman committed suicide because of dowry torture by her husband's family. Under which of the following sections is this incident covered?

BNS - BHARATIYA NYAYA SANHITA
questions.solution:
This incident can be considered a dowry death. Dowry death is defined under section 304B IPC.

According to this, if the husband or his relative subjects the woman to cruelty or harassment in demand of dowry within 7 years of marriage; they shall be deemed to have caused her death. The punishment for such cases is imprisonment for not less than 7 years, but may be extended to life imprisonment.

Option A: Section 63 (IPC 375) deals with rape.

Option C: Section 72 (IPC 228A) deals with imprisonment for up to 2 years and a fine for disclosure of the identity of a rape victim.

Option D: Section 100 (IPC 299) deals with culpable homicide.

questions.text:
An alleged female convict is arrested for a crime she did not commit. She was tortured by the investigating officer and was raped by him in police custody. Under which section will the inquest be done in this scenario?

IPC - Indian Penal Code

CrPC - Criminal Procedure Code

BNS - BHARATIYA NYAYA SANHITA

BNSS - BHARATIYA NAGARIK SURAKSHA SANHITA
questions.solution:
The given scenario is indicative of custodial rape. A magistrate inquest is done under BNSS Section 196 (Section 176 CrPC).

Custodial rape is defined as the offence committed by persons who are in supervisory positions indulging in sexual intercourse with women in their custody by inducing or seducing the woman by taking advantage of his official position.

BNSS 196 (Section 176 CrPC) deals with magistrate inquest in which the cause of death is not under natural circumstances. Magistrate inquest may be conducted by the District Magistrate, Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Tahsildar, or any other Executive Magistrate empowered by the State Government.

Indications for Magistrate Inquest:

  • Custodial rape
  • Death in police custody or police interrogation
  • Death in police firing
  • Death in prison, reformatories, Borstal school
  • Death in a psychiatric hospital
  • Dowry death
  • Cases of exhumation.

Other options:

Option A- BNS Section 63 (Section 375 IPC)deals with the definition of rape. In BNS 63, the Age of Consent of 15 years is replaced by 18 years in BNS. Exception 2 of Section 63 states that “sexual intercourse or acts by a man with his wife, the wife not being under 18 years of age, is not rape”.

Option B- BNS Section 68 (Section 376 IPC) deals with the punishment of rape by a person in authority. It is termed custodial rape.

Option D- BNSS Section 194 (Section 174 CrPC) deals with the police inquest. It is done in suicide, homicide, killing by any animal or machinery or accident, and death under circumstances that raise suspicion of another person committing the offence.

questions.text:
A pregnant lady was awarded a death sentence for committing murder by the session's court. However, her death sentence was converted to life imprisonment by the High Court. Which of the following sections describes this procedure?

BNS - BHARATIYA NYAYA SANHITA

BNSS - BHARATIYA NAGARIK SURAKSHA SANHITA
questions.solution:
BNSS Section 456: Commutation of capital sentence on pregnant woman i.e. If a woman sentenced to death is found to be pregnant, the High Court shall commute the sentence to imprisonment for life.

Other options:

Option A: Section 88 of BNS states that miscarriage induced not for the purpose of saving the life/good of the woman, be punished with imprisonment for 3 years. If the woman is “quick with child” the period is extended for 7 years more.

Option B: Section 94 of BNS – concealment of birth and secret disposal of the fetus are punishable.

Option C: BNSS Section 455 deals with the Commutation of death sentence in case of appeal to the Supreme Court.
